status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid is installing a new gas main.  The city encourages this type of capital upgrade work.  It will provide dependable gas service to the residents as well as  eliminate future emergency repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the placement of a new gas main is well worth it.  National Grid has to install the gas main first.  Once the main has been installed, then all service connections can be made. If the city were to make National Grid pave to grade each day's trench work,  it would cause multiple seams along the trench. More importantly, every service connection needs to be cut into the trench.  If we were to pave the trench every day,  this would result in 2 by 2 patches inside the trench area, resulting in a very poor final product. In order to have the best final paving, the city allows the utility company to leave the trench down low until all service connections are made and then pave the trench all at once, resulting in a smooth, level final trench repair. Service laterals are topped within 24 hours of excavation. What the constituent is observing is the trench left down low in preparation for one continuous final paving operation. We do require that the contractor place florescent orange signs ahead of the construction informing motorists that the trench ahead is down low. The work is expected to be completed within 2 weeks. If you have any questions you can call the Inspector Jessica Porder   at 781-603-9921. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid responding to a gas leak on your street activated an emergency permit. Emergency work must be performed no matter what time of day or night in the interest of public safety and the protection of private property. This proved to be a very difficult repair, resulting in National Grid working into the night. I called National Grid and told them of your issues with the work. They mentioned Dig Safe requirements which requires the work to held up for a period of time. The supervisor of National Grid Terry Cleary wants you to give her a call so she can thoroughly explain why the work has been scheduled the way it has. Terry's number is 617-822-5424. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work caused. If you are unhappy with Terry's response, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: For the second time this week we have a National Grid crew tearing up our street at 11pm. I get that they need to address gas issues quickly, but I can't imagine that standing around for 5 hours before deciding to begin is quickly. I also find it hard to believe that gas work can only be done between the hours of 10-12 at night.  Common sense would probably dictate that you not do this type of demolition on the same street at these hours twice in one week. The type of demolition they are doing isn't light either. Our building is actually shaking as a result of the backhoe pounding against the pavement. I'm not sure what we and our neighbors have done to upset National Grid so egregiously, but whatever we did I repent and ask for their forgiveness. Just please have them stop doing late night work in Shawmut for at least a week. Seems like a reasonable request so hoping you can make it happen. Now it's time to try sleep before the daily 5am parade of jets taking off gently awakens me.

This may seem like a non issue .. it's only leaves.. it is an issue.. piles of leaves invite rodents. Decaying leaves are a known mold and allergen producers...not to mention a destroyer of lawns but who cares about lawns .. I would think the city would care about the rodent issue at the very least.  Whether my lawn is destroyed or I have a fall and spring health issue due to this pile of rotten mold producing leaves, I don't expect the city would care about..

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid is installing a new gas mains  in your neighborhood.  These gas mains could be almost 100 years old, and obviously need replacement.  The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. The work is almost complete, they need to tie in the services to the homes along the new replacement limits. Any trench that is not smooth and level at the end of the job we will require the contractor to mill and pave the trench over. description: The SL4 Bus stop at this corner isn't as logical or helpful as it could be to passengers during winter: 1) The enclosed bus/T stop has 1 very wide opening and then 2 smaller openings. Despite the top heater, the wind blows right through all these openings. Is it not possible to close at least 1 of the smaller openings (if not both on the back side)? Also, I just sat here in the cold watching the SL4 bus drive 100ft before the stop, and then park itself at that corner while waiting an extra 8mins. It waited there until the scheduled time to start the route... and only then did it drive that extra 100ft to pick us up at the official stop (enclosure I just mentioned). If the buses are going to wait here to start their route at the designated time, couldn't they at least be courteous enough to wait in front of the stop and let the future passengers onboard so they're warm? (Especially since this enclosure doesn't actually keep people warm)?
